metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (automatic weather station of Dashalong station, 2020)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from the automatic weather station (AWS) at the observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Dashalong station from January 1 to December 31, 2020. The site (98.941° E, 38.840° N) was located on a swamp meadow surface in the Longshatan, which is near west of Qilian county, Qinghai Province. The elevation is 3739 m. The installation heights and orientations of different sensors and measured quantities were as follows: air temperature and humidity profile (HMP45C; 5 m, north), wind speed and direction profile (010C/020C; 10 m, north), air pressure (PTB110; in the tamper box on the ground), rain gauge (TE525M; 10 m), four-component radiometer (CNR1; 6 m, south), two infrared temperature sensors (SI-111; 6 m, south, vertically downward), soil heat flux (HFP01; 3 duplicates, -0.06 m), soil temperature profile (109ss-L; 0, -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m), and soil moisture profile (CS616; -0.04, -0.1, -0.2, -0.4, -0.8, -1.2, and -1.6 m).
The observations included the following: air temperature and humidity (Ta_5 m; RH_5 m) (℃ and %, respectively), wind speed (Ws_10 m) (m/s), wind direction (WD_10 m) (°), air pressure (press) (hpa), precipitation (rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, incoming shortwave radiation; UR, outgoing shortwave radiation; DLR_Cor, incoming longwave radiation; ULR_Cor, outgoing longwave radiation; Rn, net radiation) (W/m^2), infrared temperature (IRT_1 and IRT_2) (℃), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2 and Gs_3) (W/m^2), soil temperature (Ts_0 cm, Ts_4 cm, Ts_10 cm, Ts_20 cm, Ts_40 cm, Ts_80 cm, Ts_120 cm, and Ts_160 cm) (℃), and soil moisture (Ms_4 cm, Ms_10 cm, Ms_20 cm, Ms_40 cm, Ms_80 cm, Ms_120 cm, and Ms_160 cm) (%, volumetric water content).
The data processing and quality control steps were as follows: (1) The AWS data were averaged over intervals of 10 min for a total of 144 records per day. The missing data were denoted by -6999. (2) Data in duplicate records were rejected. (3) Unphysical data were rejected. (4) The data marked in red are problematic data. (5) The format of the date and time was unified, and the date and time were collected in the same column, for example, date and time: 2020-9-10 10:30. (6) Finally, the naming convention was AWS+ site no. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: The alpine region is important in riverine and watershed ecosystems as a contributor of freshwater, providing and stimulating specific habitats for biodiversity. In parallel, recent climate change, human activities, and other perturbations may disturb hydrological processes and eco-functions, creating the need for next-generation observational and modeling approaches to advance a predictive understanding of such processes in the alpine region. Water resources in the alpine region are headwaters that need to be regulated to sustain downstream ecosystems. However, perturbations induced by nature/climate change and human activities in recent years have significantly reformed hydrological processes and eco-functions. Accurate estimation and prediction of hydrological processes and their key impact factors has since become crucial.

Unfortunately, the scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research yet motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments. In comparison with the observations, using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation could improve the prediction of hydrological processes. However, due to the complexities of the earth system, there exist various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data (especially in the alpine region), which have to be validated and calibrated. In summary, to fill the knowledge gap and promote alpine region hydrology research, an integrated, distributed and multiscale observation dataset is essential and expected to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing data, allow the evaluation of distributed models and ultimately improve a predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions. In alpine hydrology, in addition to consistent hydrometeorological data obtained from distributed meteorological stations, snow cover and frozen ground are two important indexes and driving forces that manipulate hydrological processes. The maximum snow water equivalent (SWE) before ablation determines the storage of snowmelt – a major source of freshwater in the alpine region, while freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs) and soil moisture within the active layer alter water infiltration and, consequently, surface runoff and groundwater. To promote alpine hydrology research, the International Network for Alpine Research Catchment Hydrology (INARCH) was launched in 2015 by the Global Energy and Water Exchanges (GEWEX) project of the World Climate Research Programme (WCRP), involving 18 catchments around the world. The INARCH has since connected individual observatories into an international network and data-share platform to lead frontier research on alpine region hydrometeorology and snow observation. Another community-based observation network, the Circumpolar Active Layer Monitoring (CALM) network, was initiated in the early 1990s to observe the response of the active layer and near-surface permafrost to climate change. The Heihe River Basin (HRB) is the second largest inland river basin in China and is known for its heterogeneous landscapes, diverse ecosystems, unique geographical characteristics and climate change over recent decades. As a major component of the ecohydrological processes in the arid/semi-arid HRB, the alpine hydrological processes, especially those related to snow cover and frozen ground in the upper reaches, have great impacts on runoff in the mountainous region, which then regulate agricultural development in the middle reaches and the ecosystems of the lower reaches.

In recent years, with climate warming, permafrost degradation has significantly affected runoff and the carbon cycle (Peng et al., 2016; Gao et al., 2018). Snow cover is widely distributed with unique characteristics in the study area. In the high-altitude mountainous region (elevation > 3800 m), influenced by the local microclimate and low temperature, snowfall could occur in any season. Temporary snow is the major snow cover type in the region at middle and low elevations because strong solar radiation and high air temperature lead to fast melting and sublimation of the snow. Drifting snow is also commonly observed in the region, which may lead to the redistribution of snowpack in high elevation regions (Essery et al., 1999; Li et al., 2014).

Blowing (drifting) snow is commonly observed in the Qilian mountain due to its high altitude and complex terrain. It is important to estimate the occurrence of blowing snow because it may cause redistributions of the snow cover and influence the sublimation of snow.

Soil heat conductivity is difficult to analyze because it is a function of soil density, soil moisture content (ice content in frozen ground), and soil temperature, which cannot be easily calculated using a simple formula. Therefore, site observations can be utilized to evaluate the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models.
research objective: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China.
This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years.

The associated open-access datasets include high-quality hydrometeorological data with specific respect to snow and frozen ground observations at the sub-basin and basin scales, which aims to address a variety of scientific questions including but not limited to: (1) how to provide accurate and effective forcing data for alpine hydrological models, (2) how to integrate observation, simulation and the acquired datasets for informative understanding, and (3) how perturbations (climate change and human activities) alter fundamental processes.
challenges: However, several formidable challenges, including the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, inhibit complete and consistent data collection where/when needed, which hinders the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models.

Unfortunately, the scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers, has hindered alpine hydrological modeling and associated research yet motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments. However, the above modeling efforts suffered from 1) the availability of the forcing data (only two weather stations operated by the Chinese Meteorological Administration functioned in the upper reaches of the HRB) and 2) a lack of high-quality snow and frozen ground data for parameterization.
Unfortunately, this did not work well due to the influence of strong wind. Therefore, snow density data, which can be calculated using snow depth and SWE data, are not available at present.
methods: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation.

Considering the characteristics of the study site, an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network has been established with seven automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and two superstations. At the basin scale, the observation aims to collect data for investigating the meteorological driving forces and for validation of the alpine hydrological models. At the sub-basin scale, small-scale observations and measurements focus on data such as precipitation, soil temperature and moisture, which are used to develop and improve hydrologic models, as well as to validate remote sensing products at medium to coarse resolutions (Jin et al., 2014). At the two superstations for snow cover and frozen ground observations, remote sensing products can be further validated using fine-resolution data. In total, seven AMSs, as well as the frozen ground and snow superstations (also incorporating meteorological observations), were established in the study area during the intensive observation period (IOP: 2013 -2014) to obtain the spatially distributed meteorological variables. After the IOP, four typical AMSs were selected and retained for continuous observation, which is expected to provide long-term datasets. The observed meteorological variables include wind (speed and direction), air temperature, humidity, infrared temperature, air pressure, four-component radiation, and precipitation. Accumulation and depletion processes were measured automatically at the Yakou snow superstation. The observed components included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE, measured by GammaMONitor, GMON), albedo of the snow surface and blowing (drifting) snow flux (measured by FlowCapt). Soil temperature and moisture were measured within six layers at each AMS, while evapotranspiration (ET) was observed by eddy covariance (EC) at three AMSs located in permafrost, seasonally frozen ground and a transient zone to observe freeze-thaw (FT) processes. At the sub-basin scale, a wireless sensor network (WSN) with 40 nodes was established to capture seasonal changes in soil temperature and moisture. At the A’rou frozen ground superstation, soil temperature and moisture profiles were intensively measured in eighteen layers to a depth of 3.2 m (in a nested pattern with more layers in the topsoil) to obtain the soil hydrothermal features under freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs). In addition, thermal conductivity and hydraulic conductivity in the topsoil were also measured to observe the dynamic hydrothermal processes within.

Snow depth was measured by SR50A (Campbell, USA), which determines the distance between the sensor and the target by sending out ultrasonic pulses and listening for the returning echoes reflected from the target. Snow water equivalent (SWE) was measured by GMON (CS725 GammaMONitor, Campbell, USA) from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 at a temporal resolution of 6 hr. FlowCapt (IAV, Switzerland) was used to measure the number of blowing snow grains at 3 heights (0-1 m, 1-2 m, and 2-3 m) every 10 mins.
dataset: The current study presents a suite of datasets consisting of long-term hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for investigating watershed science and functions from an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China. Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data were monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). In addition, to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, snow cover properties were collected from a snow observation superstation using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. High-resolution soil physics datasets were also obtained to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation. The updated datasets were released to scientists with multidisciplinary backgrounds (i.e., cryosphere science, hydrology, and meteorology), and they are expected to serve as a testing platform to provide accurate forcing data and validate and evaluate remote sensing products and hydrological models for a broader community.

This paper introduces the infrastructure of the integrated alpine hydrology observation network in the HRB and the complete datasets collected in recent years. Composed of seven standard hydrometeorological stations, one snow superstation and one frozen ground superstation, the observation network serves as an integrated research platform aiming to provide prominent datasets (e.g., hydrometeorology, snow, and frozen ground) of the hydrometeorological processes in the upper reaches of the HRB, which is expected to support alpine region hydrological model development and simulations along with remote sensing observation.

A comprehensive snow dataset from the Yakou snow superstation has been updated since the summer of 2013. The observed snow variables included snow depth, snow water equivalent (SWE) and blowing (drifting) snow. Data obtained from 2014/1/1 to 2017/12/31 are summarized in Figure 4, with additional plots for precipitation, ET, soil temperature and moisture. The datasets are available from 2012/12/05 to 2017/12/31, with intermittent loss mostly due to power loss and sensor malfunctions at high altitudes.

In this paper, a suite of alpine hydrology datasets observed from an integrated, distributed and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network in the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) is presented.

Concept Completion.Question: What are the key components measured in a multiscale observation network for alpine hydrology?
Concept Completion.Answer: air temperature, humidity, air pressure, wind speed and direction, four-component radiation, precipitation, snow depth, snow water equivalent, soil temperature and moisture, soil heat flux

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in an alpine region might be established to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes?
Example.Answer: An integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network in an alpine region can be established by connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and superstations that use state-of-the-art techniques and instruments. For example, snow cover properties can be collected from a snow observation superstation, while high-resolution soil physics datasets can capture freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation. This network aims to provide data for validating remote sensing products and improving alpine hydrological models.

Example.Question: What is an example of the challenges faced in collecting consistent meteorological data in alpine regions?
Example.Answer: In alpine regions, formidable challenges such as a cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography inhibit complete and consistent data collection. These challenges hinder the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models because they result in data scarcity. For instance, the availability of forcing data is limited, with only a few weather stations operating in certain regions, and high-quality snow and frozen ground data may be lacking for parameterization.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of a dataset that integrates hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data for the purpose of investigating watershed science?
Example.Answer: A dataset that integrates hydrometeorological, snow cover, and frozen ground data can be created from an observation network in regions such as the upper reaches of the Heihe River Basin (HRB) in China. This network includes automatic meteorological stations and superstations to monitor gap-free meteorological and hydrological data. By capturing snow accumulation and ablation processes, as well as freeze-thaw processes, the dataset serves a multidisciplinary scientific community to validate remote sensing products and improve alpine hydrological models.

Definition.Question: What is an 'integrated, distributed and multiscale observation network' in the context of alpine hydrology research?
Definition.Answer: An 'integrated, distributed and multiscale observation network' refers to a comprehensive system designed to collect data across various spatial scales and integrate different types of observations. In the context of alpine hydrology research, it involves multiple automatic meteorological stations and superstations to capture diverse hydrometeorological data, snow cover, and frozen ground properties, facilitating a better understanding of watershed science and processes.

Definition.Question: What are 'freeze-thaw cycles' and how do they impact alpine hydrological processes?
Definition.Answer: Freeze-thaw cycles (FTCs) are the periodic freezing and thawing of the soil and water within the active layer in alpine regions. These cycles impact alpine hydrological processes by altering water infiltration, affecting surface runoff and groundwater dynamics, and influencing soil temperature and moisture content, which are critical to understanding the ecohydrological functions in these regions.

Definition.Question: What is 'blowing (drifting) snow' and why is it significant in alpine research?
Definition.Answer: 'Blowing (drifting) snow' refers to the movement of snow particles caused by wind, which is common in high-altitude and complex terrain areas like the Qilian mountains. It is significant in alpine research because it can lead to redistributions of snowpack, influence the sublimation of snow, and consequently affect the hydrological processes and water resources in alpine regions.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods of automatic meteorological stations in the Heihe River Basin compare to those used in the Qilian Mountain region for observing meteorological variables?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection methods in the Heihe River Basin involve a network of automatic meteorological stations that monitor gap-free meteorological and hydrological data, capturing snow accumulation and ablation processes using advanced techniques. In contrast, the Qilian Mountain region employs automatic meteorological stations focusing on observing air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and direction, along with soil temperature and moisture using a distributed observation network. Both regions aim to address challenges related to high altitudes and complex topography.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when collecting data in alpine regions compared to arid/semi-arid regions within the Heihe River Basin?
Comparison.Answer: In alpine regions of the Heihe River Basin, challenges include harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, which inhibit complete data collection and affect remote sensing technologies and model development. In arid/semi-arid regions, challenges focus on the variability of ecohydrological processes and the need for accurate estimation of hydrological processes due to climate change and human activities. Both regions require integrated observation networks to overcome these challenges.

Interpretation.Question: How do the complexities of the earth system influence the validation and calibration of remote sensing data in alpine hydrology research?
Interpretation.Answer: In alpine hydrology research, the complexities of the earth system create various sources of uncertainties in remote sensing data, especially in alpine regions. These complexities necessitate validation and calibration using integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation datasets that provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling and allow for the evaluation of distributed models.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can integrated observation networks enhance the understanding of hydrological processes and eco-functions in alpine regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrated observation networks, consisting of automatic meteorological stations and superstations, can enhance understanding by providing high-quality hydrometeorological data and detailed observations of snow cover and frozen ground. These networks aim to provide accurate forcing data for hydrological models, validate remote sensing products, and improve the predictive understanding of the impacts of climate change and human activities on hydrological processes and eco-functions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors lead to the scarcity of observation data in the alpine region, particularly hindering alpine hydrological modeling and research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The scarcity of observation data in the alpine region is mainly due to the difficulties of access and technological barriers. These challenges are exacerbated by the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, which inhibit complete and consistent data collection where and when needed, thereby hindering alpine hydrological modeling and associated research.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it crucial to develop integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation networks for hydrological research in the alpine region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: An integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network is crucial for hydrological research in the alpine region because it provides accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validates remote sensing data, and allows the evaluation of distributed models. This approach aids in improving the predictive understanding of alpine hydrological processes and ecosystem functions, addressing the complexities and uncertainties in the earth system, particularly snow cover and frozen ground influences on hydrological processes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What challenges might arise from the deployment of automatic meteorological stations in alpine regions, and how could these challenges affect data collection efforts?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Deploying automatic meteorological stations in alpine regions presents challenges such as harsh climate conditions, high altitude, and complex topography, which can hinder complete and consistent data collection. These challenges may lead to data scarcity, impacting the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models. Additionally, strong winds can affect certain measurements, such as snow density, leading to gaps in data availability and potentially impacting the accuracy of parameterization in alpine hydrologic models.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the establishment of a snow superstation affect the understanding of snow accumulation and ablation processes in alpine regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The establishment of a snow superstation can greatly enhance the understanding of snow accumulation and ablation processes in alpine regions by using state-of-the-art techniques and instruments to collect detailed snow cover properties. This setup allows for automatic measurement of snow depth, snow water equivalent, albedo of the snow surface, and blowing snow flux, thereby providing high-resolution data that can be used to validate remote sensing products and improve hydrological models. This comprehensive dataset can help address uncertainties in snow distribution and dynamics, ultimately leading to better predictions of freshwater resources.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals behind the collection of high-resolution soil physics datasets in the context of freeze-thaw processes in the alpine region?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to capture the freeze-thaw processes from a frozen ground observation superstation to better understand the dynamics of soil temperature and moisture, which are critical for evaluating the parameterization of alpine hydrologic models and understanding water infiltration, surface runoff, and groundwater in alpine environments.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it necessary to use state-of-the-art techniques and instruments for observing snow cover properties in alpine regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The necessity arises from the need to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes accurately, which are vital for understanding hydrological dynamics in alpine regions. This includes providing data for investigating watershed science, validating remote sensing products, and improving predictive models of hydrological processes and eco-functions in the context of climate change and human activities.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can an observation network be structured to effectively capture multiscale hydrometeorological data in alpine regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: An integrated, distributed, and multiscale hydrometeorological observation network can be established by deploying automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and superstations for snow cover and frozen ground observations. These stations should capture data such as wind speed and direction, air temperature, humidity, infrared temperature, air pressure, four-component radiation, and precipitation. At the sub-basin scale, additional measurements like soil temperature and moisture should be collected using wireless sensor networks to improve hydrologic models and validate remote sensing products.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies can be employed to address the challenges of data scarcity and technological barriers in alpine hydrology research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address data scarcity and technological barriers, the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments is recommended. This includes using remote sensing data combined with data assimilation techniques to improve the prediction of hydrological processes. Establishing integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation networks with automatic meteorological stations and superstations can help provide accurate forcing data for hydrological modeling, validate remote sensing products, and improve the predictive understanding of hydrological processes and ecosystem functions.

Enablement.Question: What conditions are necessary to establish a comprehensive alpine hydrology observation network in remote regions?
Enablement.Answer: An integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network is essential, which includes automatic meteorological stations (AMSs), snow observation superstations, and frozen ground superstations. This setup must account for the cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography to ensure consistent data collection.

Enablement.Question: How do technological advancements enable the capture of freeze-thaw processes in soil within alpine hydrology research?
Enablement.Answer: The use of high-resolution soil physics datasets, obtained from a frozen ground observation superstation, captures freeze-thaw processes. This includes the use of soil temperature and moisture measurements across multiple layers, and the inclusion of thermal and hydraulic conductivity measurements to observe dynamic hydrothermal processes.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the validation of remote sensing data in high-altitude alpine regions?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing data can be validated using fine-resolution data obtained from snow and frozen ground superstations. This involves using state-of-the-art techniques to capture snow accumulation and ablation processes, as well as detailed measurements of snow depth and snow water equivalent (SWE).

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection in alpine regions face significant challenges, and how do these challenges affect the quality and consistency of datasets collected?
Expectation.Answer: The cold and harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography in alpine regions create formidable challenges for data collection. These factors can inhibit complete and consistent data collection, which in turn hinders the development of remote sensing technologies and alpine hydrological models. The scarcity of observation data due to these challenges can affect the quality and consistency of datasets collected.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected outcomes of integrating observation, simulation, and acquired datasets in alpine hydrological research, and why might these outcomes not always be realized?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of observation, simulation, and acquired datasets aims to provide accurate and effective forcing data for alpine hydrological models, improve understanding, and allow for validation of remote sensing products. However, these outcomes might not always be realized due to the complexities of the earth system, uncertainties in remote sensing data, and challenges in acquiring high-quality snow and frozen ground data for parameterization.

Expectation.Question: Why is it essential to develop next-generation ecosystem observation networks in alpine regions, and what obstacles might hinder their full implementation?
Expectation.Answer: Next-generation ecosystem observation networks are essential in alpine regions to advance predictive understanding of hydrological processes and eco-functions, particularly in response to climate change and human activities. However, obstacles such as technological barriers, difficulties in accessing remote and harsh environments, and the need for high-quality data can hinder their full implementation.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of the current data collection methods in capturing the full range of hydrometeorological variables in the alpine region?
Judgmental.Answer: The current data collection methods are effective in capturing a wide range of hydrometeorological variables through an integrated, distributed, and multiscale observation network. This includes the use of multiple automatic meteorological stations and specialized superstations for snow and frozen ground observations. However, challenges such as harsh climate conditions and complex topography can hinder complete and consistent data collection.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges faced in maintaining continuous and high-quality data collection in the alpine region, and how might these be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in maintaining continuous and high-quality data collection in the alpine region are significant, primarily due to the cold climate, high altitude, and complex terrain which complicate access and data collection. Addressing these challenges may require advancements in remote sensing technologies and the establishment of more resilient observation networks to ensure data availability and quality.

Judgmental.Question: How do you assess the potential for expanding and refining datasets related to snow cover and frozen ground in alpine regions to improve hydrological models?
Judgmental.Answer: Expanding and refining datasets related to snow cover and frozen ground in alpine regions holds significant potential to improve hydrological models. By integrating snow cover properties and freeze-thaw process data from specialized superstations with remote sensing data validation, the datasets can provide more accurate forcing data, validate models, and reduce uncertainties in hydrological predictions for alpine regions.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how data collection methods are adapted to overcome the harsh climate and complex topography challenges in alpine regions.
Assertion.Answer: To address the challenges of harsh climate, high altitude, and complex topography, an integrated, distributed, and multiscale hydrometeorological – snow – frozen ground observation network has been established with seven automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and two superstations. These methods include the use of state-of-the-art techniques and instruments at snow observation superstations, as well as high-resolution soil physics datasets to capture freeze-thaw processes.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how reliable data can be collected consistently in remote and technologically challenging alpine regions.
Assertion.Answer: Gap-free meteorological and hydrological data are monitored from an observation network connecting a group of automatic meteorological stations (AMSs). Despite the challenges, the scarcity of observation data has motivated the development of next-generation ecosystem observation networks and experiments to ensure reliable data collection.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the data collection strategies used for capturing meteorological and soil data within the alpine region, considering the challenges posed by the environment.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection strategies in the alpine region involve using automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) and superstations for snow and frozen ground observations. These setups are designed to capture data on snow accumulation, ablation processes, and soil physics while considering environmental challenges such as cold climate, high altitude, and complex terrain. Advanced instruments and a wireless sensor network are employed to gather comprehensive datasets, despite difficulties in data collection due to harsh conditions.
